explanation: The Lorentz group is the set of linear transformations that preserve the Minkowski metric and therefore leave the spacetime interval invariant. A four-vector is any object whose components transform with a Lorentz matrix, ensuring that Minkowski inner products are frame-independent. This formalism is the standard language for relativistic kinematics and for writing Lorentz-covariant field theories (electromagnetism, QFT).

definitions.definition: Spacetime position 4-vector; in an inertial frame one can take `x = (c*t, x, y, z)^T`.
Minkowski squared interval associated with `x`, defined by `s^2 = x^T * eta * x`.
Minkowski metric matrix (here signature `(+,-,-,-)`), e.g. `eta = diag(1,-1,-1,-1)`.
Lorentz transformation matrix acting on 4-vectors (the linear part of an inertial-frame coordinate change).
Generic four-vector written as a column vector of components in a given inertial frame.
Another generic four-vector written as a column vector of components in the same inertial frame.
The transformed four-vectors in the primed inertial frame: `V' = Lambda*V`, `W' = Lambda*W`.
Transpose operation on vectors/matrices (e.g. `x^T` is the row-vector transpose of `x`).
Time coordinate in a chosen inertial frame.

derivation.description: In special relativity, represent events by a 4-vector `x = (c*t, x, y, z)^T` and define the Minkowski metric `eta` (signature `(+,-,-,-)`). The spacetime interval is the quadratic form `s^2 = x^T*eta*x`.

Between inertial frames, focus on the linear part of the coordinate change (translations do not affect intervals of differences). Write the transformation as a matrix acting on 4-vectors: `x' = Lambda*x`. Any four-vector `V` transforms the same way by definition: `V' = Lambda*V`.
derivation.equation: x' = Lambda * x;  V' = Lambda * V

derivation.description: Compute the squared interval in the primed frame using `x' = Lambda*x`: `s'^2 = (x')^T*eta*(x') = (Lambda*x)^T*eta*(Lambda*x)`.
Use `(Lambda*x)^T = x^T*Lambda^T` to pull `x` out: `s'^2 = x^T*(Lambda^T*eta*Lambda)*x`.

Impose invariance of the interval for all events (equivalently, for all 4-vectors `x`): require `s'^2 = s^2`. Since this must hold for arbitrary `x`, the matrices multiplying the quadratic form must match, giving the Lorentz condition `Lambda^T*eta*Lambda = eta`.

The same algebra shows invariance of the Minkowski scalar product of any two four-vectors. With `V' = Lambda*V` and `W' = Lambda*W`, we get `(V')^T*eta*W' = V^T*(Lambda^T*eta*Lambda)*W = V^T*eta*W` using the Lorentz condition.

The Lorentz condition implies an explicit inverse formula. Multiply `Lambda^T*eta*Lambda = eta` on the left by `eta` and on the right by `eta` (noting `eta^(-1) = eta` for this signature) to obtain `Lambda^(-1) = eta*Lambda^T*eta`.

Define the (full) Lorentz group as the set of real invertible `4x4` matrices satisfying the Lorentz condition: `O(1,3) = {Lambda in GL(4,RR) : Lambda^T*eta*Lambda = eta}`. The group property follows from closure under matrix multiplication and the inverse formula above.
derivation.equation: O(1,3) = {Lambda in GL(4,RR) : Lambda^T * eta * Lambda = eta}

code: # Step 1: Define Minkowski metric (signature +---) and a standard Lorentz boost in the x-direction.
# Steps 3–5 (eq2): Verify the Lorentz condition Lambda^T * eta * Lambda = eta for the boost.
assert sp.simplify(Lambda_boost.T * eta * Lambda_boost - eta) == sp.zeros(4)
# Step 6 (eq4): Verify invariance of Minkowski inner product for arbitrary four-vectors V, W.
V0, V1, V2, V3 = sp.symbols('V0 V1 V2 V3')
W0, W1, W2, W3 = sp.symbols('W0 W1 W2 W3')
# Step 7: Verify the inverse formula Lambda^{-1} = eta * Lambda^T * eta for this signature.
# Step 8: Demonstrate closure by composing a boost with a spatial rotation (still Lorentz).
assert sp.simplify(R_xy.T * eta * R_xy - eta) == sp.zeros(4)
assert sp.simplify(Lambda_comp.T * eta * Lambda_comp - eta) == sp.zeros(4)

references.citation: Einstein, A. (1905). On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies. *Annalen der Physik*, 17, 891–921.
Lorentz, H. A. (1904). Electromagnetic phenomena in a system moving with any velocity smaller than that of light. *Proceedings of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences*, 6, 809–831.
